qas.question: How many people attended the Lviv pre-election meetings?
How long did the warning strike last?
Where did the strike take place?
Prior to the warning strike when was the last labor strike in Lviv?
At what sight was the Bykivnia meeting held?

context: From April 20–23, 1989, pre-election meetings were held in Lviv for four consecutive days, drawing crowds of up to <a0_0>25,000<a0_0/>. The action included an <a1_0>one-hour<a1_0/> warning strike at <a2_0>eight local factories and institutions<a2_0/>. It was the first labor strike in Lviv since <a3_0>1944<a3_0/>. On May 3, a pre-election rally attracted 30,000 in Lviv. On May 7, The Memorial Society organized a mass meeting at Bykivnia, site of a <a4_0>mass grave<a4_0/> of Ukrainian and Polish victims of Stalinist terror. After a march from Kiev to the site, a memorial service was staged.
